facts.text: Civil Appeal No.155 of 1953 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEALATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.155 of 1953. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th July, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Nagpur, in Election Petition No. 3 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment and Order dated 15th July 1953 by Election Tribunal Nagpur in Election Petition No. 3 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th July, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Nagpur, in Election Petition No. 3 of 1952.B. Sen and T. P. Naik for the appellant. Veda Vyas  S. K. Kapur with him  for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Elections for two seats in Bhandara Parliamentary Constituency held on five days in December 1951 and January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bose J.-This is an appeal against a decision of the Nagpur Election Trbunal. The companytest before the tribunal was about two seats in the Bhandara Parliamentary Constituency. The elections were held on five days in December, 1951, and January, 1952.

facts.text: Thirteen candidates filed nomination papers, including the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Thirteen candidates filed numberination papers, among them the petitioner. Of these, six companytested the seat reserved for the Scheduled Castes. -One of these was Gangaram Thaware who has since died.

facts.text: Six candidates contested the seat reserved for Scheduled Castes (Mahar caste).

anchor.surface_text: Of these, six companytested the seat reserved for the Scheduled Castes. -One of these was Gangaram Thaware who has since died. The Scheduled Caste in question is the Mahar caste.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware born a Mahar but joined Mahanubhava Panth later.

anchor.surface_text: Objection was taken to Thawares numberination for the reserved seat on the ground that he was number a Mahar. It is admitted that he was born a Mahar, but later in life he joined the Mabanubhava Panth.

facts.text: Objection to Gangaram Thaware's nomination succeeded; nomination rejected as not Mahar.

anchor.surface_text: The Scheduled Caste in question is the Mahar caste. Objection was taken to Thawares numberination for the reserved seat on the ground that he was number a Mahar. It is admitted that he was born a Mahar, but later in life he joined the Mabanubhava Panth. This, according to the appellant, is a sect which does number believe in caste

facts.text: Appellant contended joining Mahanubhava Panth ceased membership of Mahar caste.

anchor.surface_text: This, according to the appellant, is a sect which does number believe in caste, and alternatively that it forms a separate caste in itself The companytention was that when Gangaram Thaware joined the Panth he ceased to be a member of the Mahar caste The objection succeeded and his numberination was rejected.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held rejection of Gangaram Thaware's nomination improper; he continued as Mahar.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held that the rejection of Gangaram Thawares numberination was improper as he companytinued to be a member of the Mahar caste despite his companyversion to the tenets of the Mahanubhava. Panth.

facts.text: Tularam Sakhare elected for Scheduled Caste seat, Chaturbhuj Jasani for general seat.

anchor.surface_text: That left six candidates of whom three were eligible for the reserved seat. The two who were elected were Tularam Sakhare, for the Scheduled Caste seat, and chaturbhuj, Jasani, number the general seat.

facts.text: Chaturbhuj Jasani's election challenged under section 7(d) Representation of the People Act 1951 for interest in contract for supply of goods to Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Jasanis election was challenged on the ground that he was subject to the disqualifications set out in section 7  d  of the Representation of the People Act  Act XLIII of 1951  as he was interested in a companytract for the supply of goods to the Central Government.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held Chaturbhuj Jasani disqualified due to contract with Central Government; set aside whole election.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that Chaturbhuj Jasani had a companytract with the Central Government, so he was disqualified. Accordingly it set aside the whole election.

facts.text: Chaturbhuj Jasani partner in Moolji Sicka Company, firm of bidi manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: Chaturbhuj Jasani was, and still is, a partner in the firm of Moolji Sicka Company, and it is said that at all material times the firm had- a companytract for the supply of bidis to the Government for the troops.

facts.text: Moolji Sicka Company had arrangement to supply bidis to Canteen Stores (Government) for troops.

anchor.surface_text: Moolji Sicka Company is a firm of bidi manufacturers. The Central Government was interested in stocking and purchasing bidis for sale to its troops through its canteens. Accordingly, it placed two of the brands of bidis manufactured by this firm on its approved list and entered into an arrangement with the firm under which the firm was to sell, and the Government was to buy from the firm, from time to time, these two brands of bidis.

facts.text: Crucial dates: 15th November 1951 (last date for nominations), 14th February 1952 (results declared).

anchor.surface_text: The crucial dates with which we are companycerned are 15th November, 1951, the last date for putting in the numberinations, and 14th February, 1952, the date on which the results were declared.

facts.text: Exhibit C tabular statement shows Moolji Sicka Company had contracts for bidis with Canteen Stores between relevant dates, accepted by both sides.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit C is a tabular statement which sets out the dealings between the parties during certain months. It is accepted as companyrect by both sides. The following extracts from this statement show that Moolji Sicka Company had an interest in a series of companytracts for the sale of bidis to the Canteen Stores at and between the relevant dates.

facts.text: Various contracts aggregating Rs. 15,39,345 outstanding between 15 Nov 1951 and 14 Feb 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This statement reveals that various companytracts aggregating Rs. 15,39,345-6-0 less some small sums for railway freight, were outstanding at one time or another between the two crucial dates and that payments in discharge of these liabilities were made at various dates between 15th November, 1951, and 20th March, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court held contracts subsisted on crucial dates; Jasani had share/interest as partner.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that these companytracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952, and that as Chatturbhuj Jasani, the appellant, was a partner in the firm he also had both a share and an interest in them on the crucial dates.

facts.text: Supreme Court held contracts not void despite not expressed in name of President under Art 299(1) Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the companytracts in question here are number void simply because the Union Government companyld number have been,sued on them by reason of article 299 1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Tribunal: Jasani disqualified under Sec 7(d).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was-right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware stood as Scheduled Caste (Mahar) candidate; nomination rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We number turn to Gangaram Thaware. He stood as a Scheduled Caste candidate and his numberination was rejected on the ground that he did number belong to the Scheduled Caste in question, namely the Mahars.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Gangaram Thaware continued to be Mahar despite joining Mahanubhava Panth.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, applying the test in Abraham v. Abraham 1 , we hold that despite his  1  9 M.I.A. 199. 199. companyversion he companytinued to be a Mahar and so his numberination form was wrongly rejected.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware married twice to Mahar girls; first wife never converted, second after marriage.

anchor.surface_text: Now companysidering Gangaram Thaware the individual we find that he was twice married and on both occasions to Mahar girls who were number Mahanubhavas at the time of their respective marriages. His first wife was never companyverted.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware led Mahar agitations and contested 1936 election as Mahar.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence also discloses that Gangaram Thaware led Mahar agitations and processions as a member and leader of the Mahar caste. In 1936 he companytested the election for the Provincial Assembly as a Mahar candidate.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Bose J. on 15 February 1954.

holdings.text: We are of opinion that it continues in being till it is fully discharged by performance on both sides.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that it continues in being till it is fully discharged by performance on both sides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects English debtor-creditor view post-execution; contract subsists until full performance including payment; prefers Irish and Indian precedents like O'Carroll and Satyendrakumar.

holdings.text: We hold therefore that these contracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952, and that as Chatturbhuj Jasani, the appellant, was a partner in the firm he also had both a share and an interest in them on the crucial dates.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that these contracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952, and that as Chatturbhuj Jasani, the appellant, was a partner in the firm he also had both a share and an interest in them on the crucial dates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhibit C shows outstanding contracts and payments between crucial dates; not fully executed by firm; partner has share and interest.

holdings.text: We accordingly hold that the contracts in question here are not void simply because the Union Government could not have been sued on them by reason of article 299(1).

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the contracts in question here are not void simply because the Union Government could not have been sued on them by reason of article 299(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 299(1) safeguards government from suit but does not void contracts; directory provision; applies Indian Contract Act sections 230(3) and 236(3); protects innocent parties while shielding government.

holdings.text: Now section 7(d) of the Representation of the People Act does not require that the contracts at which it strikes should be enforceable against the Government all it requires is that the contracts should be for the supply of goods to the Government. The contracts in question are just that and so are hit by the section.

anchor.surface_text: Now section 7(d) of the Representation of the People Act does not require that the contracts at which it strikes should be enforceable against the Government all it requires is that the contracts should be for the supply of goods to the Government. The contracts in question are just that and so are hit by the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disqualification under Sec 7(d) applies to contracts for supply regardless of enforceability against government.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subsisting contracts for supply; partner interest; not void under Art 299; Tribunal correctly applied Sec 7(d).

holdings.text: Looked at from the secular point of view, there are three factors which have to be considered (1) the reactions of the old body, (2) the intentions of the individual himself and (3) the rules of the new order.

anchor.surface_text: Looked at from the secular point of view, there are three factors which have to be considered (1) the reactions of the old body, (2) the intentions of the individual himself and (3) the rules of the new order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts secular test from Abraham v Abraham for caste membership post-conversion: old caste reaction, convert's intent, new sect rules.

holdings.text: Therefore, applying the test in Abraham v. Abraham, we hold that despite his conversion he continued to be a Mahar and so his nomination form was wrongly rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence: no outcasting by Mahars, Thaware identified as Mahar, married within caste, led agitations; Mahanubhavas admit retaining caste ties.

anchor.surface_text: Province of Bengal v. S. L. Puri 1  took a strict view and held that even letters headed Government of India did not comply with the rule in section 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

precedents.cited_proposition: strict compliance required even for letters headed Government of India

precedents.citation: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: the same view was taken of article 166 1 of the present Constitution by this court in Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay 2 . None of these provisions is quite the same as article 299.

precedents.cited_proposition: provisions like art 166 are directory not mandatory

precedents.citation: The Collector of Masulipatam v. Cavaly Venkata Narrainapah 1

precedents.cited_proposition: government bound by ratification of excess authority contract
